- What is your brand?
- What is your pitch deck?

# Important Concepts 
## Some basic definitions:  

- **User** is the visitor to your website (*identified across multiple sessions by unique client ID viz. stored in browser cookies*).
- **Pageview** is the count of eachtime a     user views a page on your website         (includes repeated viewings of the page     by the same user). 
- **Hits** 
are the user interactions with  the website/ page content.
 - A **Session** 
is the visit of a user to a website for a specific timeframe (eg. 30 mins).
- A **segment** breaks up users into categories or dimensions (eg. traffic source, device type, geographic location).
- **Conversion** is when a user completes an action or a goal on the website.
- **Event** is any hit or user interaction on the website (eg. downloads, clicks, form submissions, video plays etc.).
- **Source** is where the user traffic originated from (eg. Twitter).
- **Medium** is the avenue the source took to get from the source to your site (eg. Social).
- **Attribution** is an after conversion concept which basically determines or assigns value to those checkpoints which symbolize what the user did on the website or parts of the website that lead to conversion.
- **Bounce Rate** is the percentage of visitors to a particular website who navigate away from the site after viewing only one page and undertake no other action.
- **Pages Per Session** is the average number of pages viewed during each session. This also includes repeated viewings of a single page.
- **Average Session Duration** is the average length of a session based on users that visited your site in the selected date range.
- A **Dimension** is typically, an attribute of the visitor to your website (eg. videos played, #pages visited, source from where the user came, URLs, etc.).
- A **Metric** is a number (eg. counts or ratios - pageviews, visits, conversion rate etc.).
-  A **Key Performance Indicator (KPI)** is a **metric** that helps you understand how you are doing against your objectives.
- [**Custom Variables**](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/gajs/gaTrackingCustomVariables) are name-value pair tags that you can insert in your tracking code in order to refine Google Analytics tracking. With custom variables, you can define additional segments to apply to your visitors other than the ones already provided by Google Analytics. For a detailed concept on custom variables, please refer
[Page-level Vs. Session-level Vs. Visitor-level Custom Variables](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/gajs/gaTrackingCustomVariables).





## Digital Analytics is illustrated by figure 1.1 as follows: 

![Figure 1.1: The Digital Analytics Funnel](data:image/png;base64,)

where,
- **Acquisition** is creating user interest
- **Engagement** is user action on the website
- **Conversion** is the user actually buying the product/ service on the website

[To find a comprehensive list of metrics and dimensions available in Google's core API, check this out! ](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/core/dimsmets)


## List of HTTP request methods: 

- The **GET** method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.

- The **HEAD** method asks for a response identical to that of a GET request, but without the response body.

- The **POST** method is used to submit an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.

- The **PUT** method replaces all current representations of the target resource with the request payload.

- The **DELETE** method deletes the specified resource.

- The **CONNECT** method establishes a tunnel to the server identified by the target resource.

- The **OPTIONS** method is used to describe the communication options for the target resource.

- The **TRACE** method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.

- The **PATCH** method is used to apply partial modifications to a resource.


## To display all variables on the webpage: 

```for (var key in window) { console.log(key); }```


## List of HTTP Status Codes 
- 1xx (Informational): The request was received, continuing process

- 2xx (Successful): The request was successfully received, understood and accepted

- 3xx (Redirection): Further action needs to be taken in order to complete the request

- 4xx (Client Error): The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled

- 5xx (Server Error): The server failed to fulfill an apparently valid request

## What is a Facebook (FB) Pixel? 
It is FB's way of tracking everyone who visits your website and are also on Facebook. It's called a pixel because it was first meant to be a 1x1 image pixel that would then be embedded into your website. This allows FB to learn about user behaviour and product/ service functions on your website in order to then remarket the product to specific audiences on FB. 

## [What is a facebookbot?](https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-bots-guide)
